questions.scene-info: You have received a text message from DPD delivery regarding a delivery attempt. Is this a phishing attempt?

scenario.title: Atempted delivery Of your package
scenario.content: we attempted to deliver your package however there was nobody avialable to receive it. To arrange a redelivery please click the link bleow http:/delivery-dpd.coom/re-schedule

questions.explanation: This is a phishing attempt as the link goes to a unknown domain and in addition the mismatched spelling and urgent language used

questions.scene-info: Check the scenario carefully and pay close attention to the spellings and links

scenario.title: Set up e-payslips for your account
scenario.content:
We started getting all employees to change to e-payslips from paper paylsips.
 To set up your account please click this link below 
http:/payroll-setupp-free.com/setup

questions.explanation: This is a phishing email as show in a few ways. The sender is not specifically from a company domain instead it is from a generic google gmail account domain which is common by attackers to seem more legitimate. The link provided is also not legitimate as it does not link to a real platform instead it is trying to mimic one with payrolls and setup used in the link is trying to make it more legitimate.

questions.scene-info: Did you really win the lottery

scenario.content: Your number has won Â£10000 pounds! IN the weekly draw. send your name, address, account detail to this number to claim. +1 0522567898

questions.explanation: This is a phishing attempt as it claims that the person recieving this message has won a large sum of money even though they havent entered any competition. The message contains some spelling and gramamatical errors and comes from an unkown sender which is a very common indication of scam messages. It also requests personal information though SMS which is not a legitimate method to claim prizes, especially this high.

questions.scene-info: Look out for language used and the links

scenario.title: Critical Security Alert
scenario.content:
Sign in attempt blocked
john.smith@gmail.com
Somebody used your password to try to sign in to your account from an unusual location. we have taken steps to secure your account. Sign back into your account and reset your password from the link below 
https://google-security.co/reset

questions.explanation: This email scenario here represents a medium difficulty in recognising that it is phishing as it is very close to google's security alert emails. However there are some red flags which are presented if you look closer. The sender domain and the link dont match what google's actual domain is and the links also doesnt match with google's official domains. The message has very urgent language used by requesting immediate action by accessing the account through the link given.

questions.scene-info: Check who is trying to connect with you on LinkedIn

scenario.title: Joe Gazi wants to connect
scenario.content:
Hi there,

Joe Gazi (employee at X) would like to connect with you on LinkedIn.

View profile and accept connection :
https://wvw.linkedin.com.profile-view.net/profile/joe-gazi

LinkedIn respects privacy.

questions.explanation: This is phishing. The domain wvw.linkedin.com.profile-view.net/profile/joe-gazi is fake - the real domain would be profile-view.net not linkedin.com. Legitimate LinkedIn emails also use linkedin.com/ but not in this way. The email format is more professional but the URL makes it more obvious also with the use of more urgent language.

questions.scene-info: Make sure you check your links and language

scenario.content:
Thank you for using Support.To Continue with your activation please click here:
https://support.microsoft.com/en-us

questions.explanation: This is not phishing as it is an actual microsoft support message. The link provided is a legitimate microsoft link to their main support page.

scenario.title: Required: Password Policy Update
scenario.content:
Dear Team,

As part of our security enhancement initiative, all employees must update their passwords by Friday.

Please use our secure portal:
https://portal.justIT.com/password-reset

Failure to comply may result in account suspension.

Kind regards,
IT Security Team

questions.explanation: Phishing attempt. The sender email 'itsupport@justIT.com' is close but not the actual company domain (should be '@justit.com'). The urgency and threat of suspension is a pressure tactic. Legitimate IT departments typically don't send random unexpected password reset links.

questions.scene-info: Read carefully and see if you actually have a renewal

scenario.title: Payment Method Update Required
scenario.content: Your netflix subscription is set to be renewed in 3 days. Your payment method ending in **8275 has declined. Update your billing information to avoid further interuptions: https://netflix.com/account/billing-netflixsupport

questions.explanation: This is phishing. The typo 'interuptions' instead of 'interruptions' is a slight indicator. The link may also look legitimate, scammers often display text thats fake when the hyperlink when you press or hover over the link will lead to another page. Always verify payment difficulties or issues with the site directly or in their app rather than pressing links on unexpected emails.

questions.scene-info: Your project is starting to get attention

scenario.title: spot_bob starred your repository :OliL0/CyberThreat-Simulator-
scenario.content: spot_bob starred OliL0/CyberThreat-Simulator. Repository: OliL0/CyberThreat-Simulator- An interactive education project designed to teach cyber security awareness through simulated scenarios and quizzes. Stars: 10. View repository:https://github.com/OliL0/CyberThreat-Simulator- View spot_bob's profile: https://github.com/spot_bob - You're receiving this because you own this repository. Change notifications settings: https://github.com/settings/notifications

questions.explanation: This is a legitimate Github notification email for repository activity. Github sends these types of notifications when somebody stars, forks or watches your repository. The sender 'notifications@github.com' is a known legitimate sender for GitHub. The URLs 'github.com/OliL0/CyberThreat-Simulator-' and 'github.com/spot_bob' are valid GitHub profile and repository formats. The email content and structure is consistent with typical GitHub notifications, making this a genuine email rather than a phishing attempt. The notification link 'github.com/settings/notifications' is also a legitimate link. These notifications are quite commmon for public repositories.
